div.p: 1. IV:15. From Baltimore to Philadelphia.

I left the Coachman Pomphrey, to return with my Carriage and Horses to Washington, and at five this morning departed in the Steam-boat United States, Captain Trippe, from Baltimore— Among our fellow passengers were General David R. Williams of South-Carolina: Mr Bankhead, the Secretary of the British Legation and his wife, Mr Wolf Tone, and his mother Mrs Wilson, a Mr Walker of Georgetown, two or three Ladies of Captain Trippe’s family, daughters and a niece, and a Mr Spencer the husband of one of them. We arrived at half past eleven at French-town. I took for myself a Stage to Newcastle; and by my invitation, General Williams, and Mr and Mrs Bankhead, took seats in it with me— About three in the afternoon we arrived at Newcastle and embarked in the Steam-boat Captain Jenkins, for Philadelphia. Here
we landed about 6 in the Evening, and I took lodgings for the Night at Renshaw’s National Hotel, in Chesnut Street, opposite to the Bank of the United States— Mr and Mrs Bankhead lodge at the same house. R. Walsh junr called very shortly afterwards, and invited me to go and lodge at his house which I declined but agreed to spend with him part of the Evening— Charles wrote a Note to J. Sergeant, informing him of my arrival, and requesting him to call, which he did— He has very recently returned from Mexico, and spoke to me of the failure of the Congress of Tacubaya— He gave me also a private Letter from our Minister to Mexico Joel R. Poinsett, in which he advises me of an intimation given to him by the President of the Mexican States, that his recall would be demanded— Mr Sergeant thinks not favourably of the prudence of Mr Poinsett, during his residence at Mexico— I went with Mr Sergeant to his house where I saw Mrs Sergeant, Coll. Watmough; Mr Reed who accompanied Mr Sergeant to Mexico, and Miss Sergeant— Thence I went and passed the remainder of the Evening at Mr Walsh’s, where I met Jos. Hopkinson, N. Biddle, J. Vaughan, and several other persons with whom I was not acquainted— Returned about 11. in the Evening to the Hotel, where Sergeant parted from me— The heat of the day was excessive, and the dust on the road from Frenchtown to Newcastle, irksome beyond all my former experience.
2. V. From Philadelphia to New-York—

At six this Morning we embarked in the Steam Boat Trenton Captain Jenkins for Trenton. Mr J. Vaughan met me in the Street, and accompanied me to the Boat. Among the passengers were Mr and Mrs Bankhead, and Coll. Watmough, whom I invited, and who rode with me, from Trenton to New-Brunswick— There were many other Passengers; among them a man named Hoskins, an inhabitant of Burlington, who landed there; after having introduced himself to me— We landed about half-past nine at the wharf at Trenton, and embarked again at half past one in the Steam-boat Thistle at New-Brunswick— We had travelled by the Stage from Trenton through Princeton, to Kingston 14 Miles; and thence 14. Miles to New-Brunswick— At half past five in the afternoon we arrived at New-York— The ride from Trenton to New-Brunswick was excessively beclouded with dust, and scorched with heat— While on the passage between Staten-Island, and the New-Jersey shore, we had a light and very refreshing Thunder-Shower— We came to the City Hotel at New-York, where I found my wife; with Abigail S. Adams, my Son George, and Johnson Hellen— My Son John afterwards came in from Albany, whence the others had arrived this morning— John Kirke and Jane Winnull are with Mrs Adams, as attendants— She left Boston with George, and Abigail the 21st. of last Month— Went and Lodged that Night at Mr Boylston’s at Princeton— Proceeded to Worcester the 22d. to Providence the 23d. to New-York the 24th. to West-Pointand back the 25th.— To Albany the 28th. and after being there two days sick in bed, returned to reach here this morning— She has a severe return of her cough— Joseph Blunt, Charles King, and George Sullivan called upon us in the course of the Evening. I gave Sullivan a verbal answer to his Letter concerning Mr Richard Stockton of New-Jersey— I assured him, and authorised him to assure Mr Stockton, that my sentiments of regard, and respect for him had undergone no change— That the considerations upon which I had considered it my duty to appoint another person judge of the U.S. District Court in New-Jersey, were in no respect injurious to him, although of a nature which needed no explanation to him— That I could only say, Mr Southard was not peculiarly responsible for my decision; and that he had never spoken to me of Mr Stockton, but in terms of high respect and esteem— Sullivan said this communication would be grateful to the feelings of Mr Stockton, who had been hurt at not receiving the appointment of District Judge, and had been strongly apprehensive that some disservice had been done to him, in my mind— Sullivan also told me that judge Thompson of the United States Supreme Court was at home, and he thought that a call from me would be very acceptable to the judge—
3. V. Steam boat Washington—from New-York— Long-Island Sound—

I paid a visit this Morning to judge Smith Thompson at his house in Broad-way; about two Miles from the City Hotel, and had a friendly conversation of perhaps two hours, on various topics of interest— Returned to the City Hotel, and received visits from Jonathan Thompson the Collector, and Peter Stagg the Naval Officer— General Theodorus Bailey the Postmaster, with Mr Mower, Coll. Jonas Platt, with two other old Officers of the Revolutionary War, a Mr Henry of Richmond Virginia, his wife, and two Sons, Mr Clendenin
and three others from Kentucky, Commodores Tingey and Chauncey, Coll. Henderson, J. A. King, Charles and Edward King, J. P. De Wint, a Son of Mr P. C. Brooks, and several others. At 2. we dined— At 3. my family which had all met at New-York together was again separated— Mrs Adams with my son John and Johnson Hellen walked with us to the slip, where with my Sons George and Charles, and Antoine I embarked in the Steam-boat Washington, Captain Bunker the elder, which was soon upon her way. Mr George Sullivan was on board, and introduced to me two Sons of Lieutenant Governor T. L. Winthrop, who are our fellow passengers, and a Coll. Keith of South-Carolina, going with his family to pass the remnant of the Summer at Newport— Sullivan himself was going to Rockaway, in New-Jersey where his wife is— My wife with her part of our family intend before returning to Washington, to go and pass some days at Long-branch— The day was again, intensely, scorchingly hot; but on the water we found a strong breeze from the South west, which added speed to the progress of our boat, and she cut the waters at the rate of more than ten Miles an hour. We had about one hundred passengers, most of them entirely unknown to me— Mrs Johnson, a widow Lady recalled herself to my memory, as having been formerly Mary Storer of Boston, and a Mr Lamb of South-Carolina mentioned himself as having been introduced to me two or three years since at Washington. He is also going with his family to Newport— I sat with my Sons on the roof of the round house, from the moment of our departure till the going down of the Sun, and then descending on the deck conversed upon English Grammar, with a Schoolmaster named Goold Brown, the author of a grammar, and who maintained by argument that in the English language there are ten parts of Speech— He said he had examined a great number of English Grammars, and that the author of the most antient of them was the Poet Ben Jonson— The breeze continued to freshen, till near Midnight, when I retired to my birth in the Cabin.
4. V. From Steam-boat Washington. Long Island Sound, to Quincy.

There arose soon after Midnight a thick fog, which chilled the atmosphere, and slackened the speed of our progress. On going upon deck I found they were sounding for bottom, with a heavy swell, and many of the passengers Sea-sick. They continued sounding about an hour longer, when the Light-house 7 Miles below Newport, was discovered about half a mile distant— At half past seven, Coll. Keith, Mr Lamb, and their families, with several other passengers landed at the wharf at Newport— At ten, the remainder of the Passengers landed at Providence, just nineteen hours from New-York— Had the fog not arisen, our passage would have been two hours shorter— As the morning advanced the fog dispersed, and at the time when we landed at Providence, the Sun was again blazing, with all his fierceness— A signal had been made from the boat for eight Stages, which were ready at the landing, and one of them was engaged for me, to go round, and leave me at Quincy— We had therefore no other company in it. We all dined at Fuller’s Tavern, at Walpole. Parted from the other Stages at Dedham; and at five in the afternoon, 26 hours from New-York, arrived at my brother’s Residence in Quincy— Charles proceeded in the Stage to Boston. George remains with me— At 9 in the Evening; the tide serving I bathed with my brother at D. Greenleaf’s wharf— Mr Goold Brown this morning gave me a copy of his Grammar— Mr. Winchester a distinguished Victualler was one of our passengers from New-York to Providence; introduced himself to me, and held much conversation with me, upon the packing of Beef and Pork— For the time I have been upon this journey, it has been uncommonly fatiguing; and the heat and dust more annoying than I ever felt them before— But the increase of traveling on this road from Washington to Boston, within my memory, is more strongly marked every year— I believe that the number of travellers from Boston to New-York in the year 1789. the first that I went down the Sound, did not in the whole Summer, exceed that of the Passengers in the Steam-boat Washington for this single trip— Even after the Steam-boat Navigation had been 8 years in practice, when in 1817 and 18 I travelled in them between Boston and New-York, the passengers were certainly not half so numerous, and there were only two Boats in the trade—navigating three times a week, and only between New-York, New-Haven, New-London, and Norwich— There are now eight or ten Boats plying between the same Ports; more than one of which departs every day— The voyage from New-York to Providence is performed in less time than was then taken between New-York and New-London—and it is now not unusual to pass from New-York to Boston, within the 24 hours— These are among the pleasing proofs not only of the great increase of the population of this Country, but of the improvement in the condition of the People. The invention of the Steam-boats has on the average shortened the time of travelling between Washington and this place by one half. It has given facilities to the Water-passages between Baltimore and Philadelphia, and between New-York and Providence in a still greater proportion, besides the almost certainty of effecting the passages in the purposed time, instead of the former dependence upon the chances of the winds.
5. V.30. Quincy.

The Night was comfortably cool, and I rose this morning refreshed and recovered from all the fatigue of my Journey. Heard Mr Whitney in the morning from Acts 10.40.41. “Him God raised up the third day, and shewed him openly;— Not to all the people, but unto witnesses chosen before God, even to us, who did eat and drink with him after he rose from the dead.” It was communion day, and I remained and participated in that service. The afternoon Sermon was from Proverbs 9.12. “If thou be wise, thou shalt be wise for thyself: but if thou scornest, thou alone shalt bear it.” I had heard this discourse before; and the text had remained deeply impressed upon my mind; as among the most excellent of moral maxims. I came home at the close of the afternoon service, with Mr Quincy, the Mayor of Boston. He proposed to me, the immediate repayment of a sum of money which he had borrowed some Months since; a small balance of my father’s Estate, remaining in the hands of the Executors— Not having the papers at hand, I proposed to postpone this Settlement for the present. Mr Quincy returned this Evening to Boston. Degrand came out, and spent the Evening here— Brought out a number of Newspapers, and was as usual full to overflowing of politics— He asked me why I had not nominated him a Director of the Bank of the United States, and I gave him candidly the decisive reason, that he was a broker— An objection which I told him had been urged by some of his warm friends, and even by the President of the Bank, who I told him had assured me that he would take opportunities that might occur, to give him aid, in his business— He said that was so far so good, and asked if there had been other objections: I said there had; but of a nature which it would be useless for me to explain to him— They were founded upon prejudices, and were made by some of his friends as well as others— He asked how it would be if he should discontinue his business as a Broker, and be only a Commission-merchant— I told him I could not say— That it was not my custom to explain to candidates for public office, my motives for selecting others; but I had done it to him from the regard I had for him; and I could only add that I had acted under a sense of duty and of my official obligations— He complained much of the Custom-house Officers at Philadelphia, and particularly of the Deputy Collector, whom he represented as devotedly hostile to the Administration, and as abusing his Official power to injure the friends of the Administration, and to favour their opponents— And he spoke of him, as peculiarly hostile, and oppressive to him— He said that such conduct from the Officers of Government towards the friends and supporters of the Administration, made it their interest as individuals to go over to the enemy— Well, Mr Degrand, said I—do so— He said no—he should certainly not do so— I said that if the Deputy Collector, or any other Officer at the Custom house, did him injustice, he should immediately address the Secretary of the Treasury, state the fact he complained of, and demand redress— In that case the Officer would be immediately called upon to answer to the complaint, and if that should be substantiated, I would answer he should never have cause to complain of that Officer again— He mentioned two instances of petty vexations that he had endured, one of which I thought not very important, and in the other he had complied with an exaction of the Officer, which if he had inflexibly resisted, the Officer must have yielded— But he said what is indeed true, that an Officer, disposed to be partial, may in many ways favour his friends and annoy his adversaries, without coming exactly within the verge of responsible official misconduct— I said this was irremediable— I could not dismiss an Officer, for that which could not be charged as misconduct; and as to the political preferences of public Officers, in relation to the Presidency, I could take no cognizance of them— This conversation was painful to me, and mortifying to Degrand; but what I said to him, was due to candour and he recovered his good humour before he went away. Marston, Taylor, and the Whitney’s father and Son paid friendly evening visits— Mr Peter Clark is a young man who informed my Son George that he wished for a few minutes of private conversation with me for which I fixed to-morrow Morning at seven O’Clock. George was unwell this Morning; but recovered his tone in the after part of the day— The morning threatened another day of intense heat. But about ten there came up a very light easterly breeze, which through the day barely tempered the fervid effulgence of the Sun— It continued through the Evening, and as darkness came it grew so damp, and chilly, that we retired from the porch into the Parlour, and on going to bed I was prompted to close all my bed chamber windows but one, and left that only a few inches open.

Peter Clark came at seven this Morning. He is a young man, he says a native of this town; who after entering at two or three colleges, successively, has just been graduated at one of them in the State of New-York— He told me his Story, and his motive for applying to me, was to borrow 250 dollars, his best reason for which was a desire to be married immediately— I declined the proposal, for his sake as well as my own. I had visits from Mr John Whitney, brother to the Minister, and now the Representative of the town, in the Legislature of the State, and from Dr George Parkman of Boston. And in the Evening, from Mr Daniel Greenleaf and Mr Price Greenleaf. I had sent for Mr Elisha Turner, who came and I bespoke a Waistcoat and pair of Pantaloons. My brother and my Son George went in to Boston in the Stage— My brother came out in the afternoon with James Foster junr, and a horse upon trial; as I propose to purchase one— James Foster returned to Boston with my brother’s horse, and my Chaise, leaving those, in which they had come out here— I bathed with Antoine at Mr Greenleaf’s wharf at 11 this morning, and again this Evening at 10. with my brother, his two Sons John Quincy and Joseph Harrod, and Antoine— The day was one of the hottest that I ever experienced. At 1. P.M the Mercury, in the porch fronting the House, was at 101. I found myself utterly unable to write; and after dinner threw myself on the bed, from which I was soon compelled again by the heat to rise. I took from my brother’s Bookcase the two Volumes of Heron’s Junius, and read in a desultory manner, many of his Notes— Junius is a writer of great power, but the extraordinary curiosity excited by his Mask, has given him greater celebrity than he would ever have attained without it— His secret has hitherto been kept, perhaps the better, for the multiplied, and in many cases, absurd attempts to detect him— Heron after poring over him like a Dutch Professor over an antient Classic, fixes upon Dunning as the author— Woodfall, who published the Letters thought Hugh Boyd was the man— It has been almost demonstrated that Sir Philip Francis was the culprit, and Dr Waterhouse in solacing his old age with a volume of ingenious non sequiturs to prove that it was Lord Chatham— The Speeches, and avowed writings, of Lord Chatham, bear the stamp of a mind, not unequal to the composition of Junius. Burke’s, are in my opinion of a higher order— Were it ascertained that either of these was the political assassin who stabbed with the dagger of Junius, I should not add a particle of admiration for his talents, and should lose all my respect for his morals— Junius was essentially a Sophist— His Religion was infidelity— His abstract ethics, depraved—his temper, bitterly malignant, and his nervous system, timid and cowardly— The concealment of his name at the time when he wrote was the effect of dishonest fear. The perpetuation of it could only proceed from the consciousness that the disclosure of his person would be discreditable to his fame— The object of Junius, when he began to write was merely to overthrow the Administration then in power— He attacked them in a mass and individually—their measures, their capacity, their characters public and private—charged them with every crime and every vice— Afterwards he followed up his general assault, by singling out successively the Dukes of Grafton and Bedford, Lord Mansfield, Sir William Blackstone and the king himself— He magnified molehills into Mountains, inflamed pin scratches into deadly wounds; and at last abandoned his cause in despair, at the very time when he might have pursued it with most effect— But while he was battering the Ministry, upon paltry topics, that had neither root nor stem, he had declared himself emphatically and repeatedly on their side upon the only subject on which their fate, and the destiny of the Nation, altogether depended; the controversy with America— The cause that he took in the early stage of that conflict, and his disappearance from the theatre of politics, at the time when it was ripening into the magnitude of its nature, have marked Junius in my mind, as a man of small things, a splendid trifler, a pompous and shallow politician— His commentator Heron is just deep enough to admire his profundity— There is some information concerning the men and things of the time in Heron’s Notes, and dissertations, with an abundance of Scottish self-sufficiency, and prejudices— His philosophical and critical Essay upon the rise and progress of Eloquence, with its division into four Periods, has some merit, and might lead to a more profound investigation of the subject—but his overestimate of the powers and Eloquence of Junius, and the slighting manner in which he ranks him above Edmund Burke, is to me supremely ridiculous— It must however be acknowledged that in his enthusiasm for Junius, he is not alone.
The weather this Evening after the excessive heat of the day, became delightfully temperate and cool.

On rising this morning, I visited the spot of ground over which the Summer House formerly stood, and where last Autumn we planted nuts and acorns— I found ten Shagbark walnuts, nine Oaks and six horse chesnuts up. One of the walnuts but just out of the ground— We also planted lime seeds, none of which have come up— All the Oaks appear from the leaves to be of the same kind—the Chesnut Oak— After Breakfast I rode with my brother down to the Mount Wollaston farm; and on returning viewed the Stone temple now building close to the old meeting House, and which is to supply its place— This edifice for the erection of which my father partly made provision, by a donation to the Town of Quincy has been commenced by the Religious Congregational Society at this place. The Corner Stone was laid on the 11th. of June last, and the walls are already nearly 30 feet high— About noon, I bathed at the wharf with Antoine— Had a morning visit from General Dearborn the Collector of Boston, and in the afternoon from David L. Child, and Mr Agg of Washington. Mr and Mrs John B. Davis, and a Mr Wheeler of Cincinnati, a Painter; who requested me to sit to him for my picture— To this I consented, and he is to come out on Thursday Morning at ten— My brother’s eldest Son, Thomas B. Adams junr, arrived this afternoon upon a furlough of a fortnight, from West-Point, and my Son Charles came out from Boston— I paid an Evening visit to Mr Thomas Greenleaf, who has been sometime confined to his house by indisposition, but is recovering.

The Succession of visitors, occupied almost the whole of this day— Mr Jarvis the Speaker of the House of Representatives of this Commonwealth, and Dr Thomson of Charlestown came together— Mr Brooks and Mr Everett, who has just recovered from a severe illness. Mr Brooks invited me to go and pass a Sunday with him at his house in Medford; which I promised; and to send him notice by my Son Charles— Mr Appleton and Mr Bailey. Mr Appleton made some enquiries concerning the renewal of the commercial Treaty with Sweden, now in the hands of his Son, Chargé d’Affaires of the United States at Stockholm; and asked whether if he should conclude the Treaty he might not be the bearer of it himself on a leave of absence— I said I believed that could not be admitted. Mrs Lunt, and the young Ladies and gentlemen with her were here at tea— Miss Sigourney is a daughter of the late Charles Sigourney, an acquaintance of mine at Amsterdam in 1781— His eldest Son was at Washington in the Spring of 1825. with his wife who is a Poetess of some renown. Mr Luke Drury, late Collector of the Port of Bristol, Rhode-Island, was here this Evening He brought me Letters recommendatory from John Pitman, judge of the U.S. District Court in that State, and from three other respectable persons, one of them, Rector of St. Michael’s Church, at Bristol. Drury was a few days before I left Washington, dismissed from his Office of Collector, for delinquency long continued, and increasing, after repeated warnings— His appointment had originally been made under no good auspices, through the influence of James D’Wolf, then a Senator from Rhode-Island, and by the rejection of an honest man, named Bates— Mr. Drury now acknowledged and deeply lamented his delinquency— Seemed desirous of imputing it to domestic misfortunes, and his having a numerous family to support; and rather intimated than affirmed that if time had been allowed him he would have paid up his arrearages by next May— He spoke of the ruin of his fortune; of the wreck of his reputation; of the distress of his family, professed religious compunctions, and shed some tears— I thought his religion, and his tears out of place— He appeared apprehensive of further measures of rigour against him, to recover the monies due from him as Collector— I told him that if he had any proposals to make, soliciting an indulgence of time, he must address a Letter to the Secretary of the Treasury, who would do everything consistent with his public duties, to accommodate him— That I lamented his misfortune, and had with great reluctance resorted to the measure of removing him. That I could individually do nothing for him, but would readily assent to any indulgence of time, which the Secretary of the Treasury might think proper to allow— He asked if I thought he should be more likely to succeed in his application by going to Washington and addressing the Secretary in person— I said it would make no sort of difference— That if he went in person, he must still make his application in writing; and the Secretary would decide upon it in the
same manner, whether he should see him or not— I wrote little this day. Bathed at the wharf at Noon, with my Son Charles, T. B. Adams jr.J. Q. jr. and Jos. H. and Antoine— After dinner I took out from the Town Library Torcy’s Memoirs and dallied away perhaps two hours in examining the passages relating to the bribe offered by Louis the 14th. to the Duke of Marlborough, and which Junius says was only not accepted. They are in Vol. 1. p. 141— Vol. 2. p. 15. 62. 67. 79. 89. and 158. The last is the explicit authority from Louis to Torcy, to promise the Duke two, three or four Millions of Livres, according to a graduated scale of terms favourable to France, upon which by the Duke’s influence peace might be concluded— Torcy represents the Duke, as greedily avaricious, and personally interested in the continuance of the War— As having a commanding influence, and entire controul over the result of the Negotiations; but insincere, and full of dissimulation: professing an ardent desire for Peace, and a profound reverence for and personal attachment to Louis 14— Torcy says that he had at a prior period, quietly listened to proposals flattering to his passion for unbounded wealth, and intimates that they had been made through the Duke of Berwick, and the Marquis d’Allegre. Louis says that he had caused a promise of reward to be made to Marlborough, if he should deserve it by his conduct, and that he was surprised at the obstacles he had thrown in the way of the Peace, after the assurances that he had given of his wish to contribute to that event— Torcy shews that the Duke sought private interviews with him—and affectedly referred to his previous intercourse with the Duke of Berwick, and the Marquis d’Allegre, with all the particulars of which Torcy let him know that he was acquainted— He adds that the Duke most earnestly repeated the protestations of his desire to deserve the protection of the king of France, after the peace—but that he Torcy receiving no aid from the Duke, made no positive engagement with him, but held with him such discourse as was suited to confirm the expectations he had formed— But that when he spoke to the Duke about his private interests the Duke blushed, and appeared to wish to turn off the conversation— It appears on the whole, that Marlborough was willing enough to receive Louis’s money; but was not prepared to give him any equivalent for it, but heartless protestations and indefinite professions. Charles went this afternoon to Boston—
9. IV:58. Sun rising— Thunder Shower in the Night.

I took a ride this morning after Breakfast with my brother, to Braintree; and we stopped at Mr James Howards. At ten O’Clock, Mr Wheeler, the Painter from Cincinnati came, and I sat to him with various interruptions till two. He dined with us; and immediately after dinner went away, to return to Boston, in the Stage from Plymouth— The lists of visitors in the margin, on this and other days, are my only apologies for the loss of Time, which I am constantly lamenting, but never repair— Mr Winthrop, Mrs Quincy and her two daughters, called before dinner. Louisa Smith dined, and spent the day here— She is on a visit at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— Dean is a farmer, and Seller of baskets from a neighbouring town, who came from an overweening curiosity to see and talk with the President, and sold me a basket, but would not take for it more than a quarter of a dollar— Mrs Royall came from Boston, in the Stage with my Son Charles— She is going to Plymouth and travelling about the Country to make another book— She continues to make herself noxious to many persons; tolerated by some, and feared by others; by her deportment and her books, treating all with a familiarity, which often passes for impudence: insulting those who treat her with incivility, and then lampooning them in her books— Stripped of all her sex’s delicacy but unable to forfeit its privilege of gentle treatment from the other, she goes about like a virago errant in enchanted armour, and redeems herself from the cravings of indigence by the notoriety of her eccentricities, and the forced currency they give to her publications. Mr Woodward was here but a moment— The Count dal Verme introduced himself as the Son of a man of the same name, an Italian who travelled in this Country in 1788. He produced two Original Letters, dated in that year— One a Letter of Recommendation from General Washington, the other a Letter from Dr. Ezra Stiles, then President of Yale College, to the Count himself announcing to him that a degree of Doctor of Laws had been conferred upon him, at their recent Commencement— He had also a written paper, in English, purporting to be a note from his father, and a list of names of persons of distinction in this Country, from whom he states that he had received numerous kind attentions, and the note advises the Son to visit the Survivors of that list. Mr Adams is one of the names at Boston, which must have been meant for Samuel Adams: but this young man supposed it was my father, who at that time, and for five years
afterwards was absent in Europe.— I received and treated this Count with civility, but there was something so peculiar in his self-introduction, and his documents that I could not resist some distrust of his authenticity— He told me that he had come from Liverpool to New-York, and was now going to Quebec. Mr Beale and Mr Quincy paid short visits— The Mayor was somewhat exasperated against Mrs Royall, who he said was this morning near being brought up before the Police Court— I paid an evening visit at Mr John Greenleaf’s, and in my walk met Mr Marston who turned and went with me— He said he had received a Letter of complaint from his Son in Law, Henry D’Wolf of Bristol Rhode-Island, because he had not obtained for him the appointment of Collector, when Drury was removed: and said that he wanted the place the more urgently because his property had been deeply involved in the failure of George D’Wolf. I told him that circumstance alone must have prevented the appointment of Henry D’Wolf, as George D’Wolf had been the bondsman of Drury, and we believed that Drury’s delinquencies had gone principally into the sink of George D’Wolf’s debts— I bathed with Antoine at One.

I wrote to D. Brent of the Department of State. Mr Wheeler came at ten O’Clock and kept me sitting, with the interruptions of visitors, a bath with Antoine at one, and dinner at two, till five in the afternoon— He then returned to Boston, and is to come for the last sitting next Monday— Messrs. Webster, Hall and Welsh were morning visitors— The others, the names of two of whom slipped from me, came after dinner— Mr Wilson belongs to Charleston South-Carolina, and his wife is the daughter of Jeremiah Condy, who had written me that they were travelling at the North— He told me that his wife was at French’s tavern in the village, and I requested him to invite her to come and take tea with us— He said he would but thought she would be unable to leave a small child she had with her. Afterwards I received from him a Note of excuse, stating that she declined coming. Mr. T. Greenleaf called, and gave me two plans of the Temple they are building. One of the elevation, and external front—the other of the ground floor— He offered to go with me, at any time, which would suit my convenience and fix upon the spot for the tomb of my father and mother— Mr George Beale came to propose a fishing party, in the Bay, below the Light-House, to which I agreed, for a day towards the close of next week when the tide will serve— In the Evening I walked alone to Mr Quincy’s— Mrs. D. GreenleafLouisa SmithGeorge and Caroline WhitneyMiss Gray, daughter of the Minister at Jamaica Plains, T. B. Adams jr. and Elizabeth C. were there— Mr Quincy and his Son Josiah came out from Boston while we were there. I rode home with Mrs Greenleaf and Louisa Smith— My brother’s Son Isaac Hull came home from his School at Jamaica Plains.

I had the morning uninterrupted for writing. Bathed and swam from wharf to wharf with my Son Charles, the four Sons of my brother and Antoine— The weather was very damp and sultry— Returning home, and for half an hour afterwards I felt symptoms of cramp in the calf of my left leg— Another memento for caution in bathing. Messrs.MarstonMiller and Beale dined with us— Immediately after dinner, Mr Quincy called, and I rode with him in his Carriage to the Railway. We found Coll. T. H. Perkins at the Stone House which the Company built there the last Autumn— We walked with him to the Quarry were overtaken by a thunder Shower and took shelter under the shed where the Stone-cutters were at work upon the Blocks for the Bunker Hill Monument. The Railway has been about nine Months in full and successful operation, but it appears to me that there has already some impression been made on the iron tire of the way, and still more on the pine wood rail beneath it— Coll. Perkins and Mr Quincy think not, but the Colonel has made an experiment for a small space of substituting, a granite rail, in the place of the Pine-wood— This will be more durable, but may occasion the more rapid wearing out of the iron— The question still to be solved is the result of this undertaking with reference to profit— Coll. Perkins has great means, ardent public Spirit, and pertinacious enterprize— It is generally
thought that the greater part if not the whole of the expense of the work is sustained by him; and that he is liberal even to profusion in expense upon it— It has already been of great advantage to the town of Quincy, and promises to be of still more— But the danger that the Railway may prove a bill of expense to its owners casts a shade over the whole enterprize, and rather increases than diminishes— Coll. Perkins is now about commencing to build a large Hotel near the Railway— The blocks of Granite at the shed near the Quarry; are some of the most beautiful building Stones I ever saw— There is danger of accidents on the way; and Coll. Perkins himself has once been thrown from his horse over it, and fell at least 20 feet, but without much hurt, it being on soft ground— After the Shower, Mr Quincy took me home, where I found my Son George, and Mr John Winthrop with whom he had come out from Boston— Mr Winthrop returned to the City— Mr Webster and his brother had been here, while I was gone.
12. V. Sun rise— Copious Rain.

Heard Dr. Thaddeus Mason Harris, Minister of a Church at Dorchester, and just forty-years since, a graduate with me at Harvard University— His morning text was Psalm 31:19. “Oh how great is thy goodness, which thou hast laid up for them that fear thee; which thou hast wrought for them that trust in thee, before the sons of men.” That of the afternoon was 1. Corinthians 16.13. “Watch ye, stand fast in the faith, quit you like men, be strong.” The former of these Sermons was upon the goodness of God, and the latter upon the duties of men— Both were well written and impressive. Dr Harris came home with me, and dined with us. In the afternoon, I had a visit from Mr Isaac Waters, who had come out from Boston— He mentioned that the papers from New-York, arrived this day, announced the decease of Dr Horace Holley, late President of the Transylvania University; at Lexington, Kentucky— He had some months since resigned that office, and had formed a project of going to Europe; as a traveling preceptor to ten youths, whose Parents were to furnish each a thousand dollars a year for three or four years to defray the expenses of this itinerant Academy— Dr Caldwell had told me some months since of this scheme, which I then thought somewhat romantic— In pursuance of it however, Dr Holley descended the river to New-Orleans in June or July. There he found obstacles to the execution of his European tour, which led him to abandon it, and he projected opening an academy in the neighbourhood of New-Orleans— Probably this undertaking had also failed, for he had embarked with his family for New-York and died on his passage, of the yellow fever, on the 31st. of last Month— He was a man of Genius, Learning, and eloquence; so conscious of his powers, as to be discontented with the profession he had chosen; but without the Address or good fortune, like Edward Everett, after stepping from the pulpit into the professor’s Chair, to make the second and larger Stride into the forum. Waters says he was coming back to be the Pastor of a congregation now building a new Church at the South end of Boston— I spent an hour of the Evening with my Son George at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— I have had made four small wooden seedling tubs, and this afternoon planted 5 tamarind Stones and eight Pear seeds in N. 1. and 5 Tamarind stones and 6. Pear-seeds in N. 2— There is a question whether the seeds or stones from fruit of grafted or budded trees will germinate; and finding nothing upon the subject in any of the Books I have read, I am inclined to bring it to the test of experiment— In my Summer house Nursery two more of my Shagbark walnut trees have come up, making now twelve, within the Walls— The Horse Chesnuts and the Oaks appear to have come up, all nearly at the same time; but both here, and at Washington the walnuts seem to come up in succession all Summer through— In this branch of Natural History, my experiments have commenced so late in life, and are yet so little governed by a system pointing directly to useful ends that they may perhaps end in mere trifling; but that is not my intention— On the 8th. of October 1804. I planted perhaps 40 walnuts in this garden, several of which came up; the ensuing Summer— One of them was transplanted to the garden of the house where my father was born, and lives but is not yet in bearing, one only remains on the spot where the nut was planted, and at the age of 21 years, last Autumn bore perhaps 200 nuts— Most of these I planted here, or at Washington, and there are now 13 of them here, and 12 at Washington growing— But last year was my first experiment of planting acorns, and that has been partially successful here and totally failed at Washington. Coll. Perkins told me yesterday, that he thought our Pasture White Oak, well salted, as good for Ship building as the best Live Oak— This is encouragement for me to persevere in my experiments, which I would leave as at once a charge and an inheritance to my Children.
13. IV:15— Sun rose 5:1— Night cold— Day cloudy.

Isaac Hullmy brothers Son returned to School at Jamaica Plains— My Sons George and Charles went in to Boston— T. B. Adams and Elizabeth C. went also to Boston and returned this Evening. I signed a remission of Penalties for the British Barque Mary Anne, David Laidley, Master, from Belfast to Philadelphia, for an excess of 7. Passengers— A Commission to Francis Armistead, as Surveyor and Inspector of the Revenue for the Port of East River: and a Commission to John Henry Owen, as Receiver of Public Monies for the District of St. Stephens, Alabama—and enclosed them all with a Letter to the Secretary of the Treasury— I gave my Son George a check on the U.S. Branch Bank Boston in favour of S. Frothingham the Cashier to pay a draft of J. A. Smith, dated at Madrid 24. May— Mr Wheeler came out again, and I set to him from ten this Morning till 5 in the afternoon, with the interval of an hour for dinner, and the interruptions of ten or twelve of the visitors in the Margin— There was a continual succession of them through the day, and probably there were several whose names have escaped my recollection. General Boyd introduced Mr Chamberlain as a person who has been particularly friendly to me; a property for which the General himself is not distinguished. Dr Porter was upon his return with his niece from East Bridgwater where he had been yesterday to preach— Mr Lloyd asked some questions respecting the state of our Negotiations with Great Britain, and Mr Parker expressed his disapprobation of the heavy expenses incurred in the City of Boston, by the erection of the New-Market house— He says it has saddled upon the City a debt of at least 100,000 dollars; and that the income from the rent of the buildings is not equivalent to the interest of the debt. Jones of the Athenaeum came to invite me to visit that Establishment in connection with which he is exhibiting a Panorama. Dr Welsh, at the age of 75. came out from Boston after dinner, on horseback; and visited the Railway, on his return— Mr T. K. Jones engaged me to dine with him next Wednesday week at Dorchester. General Anderson who came with Mr Thayer is an Engineer appointed by the Secretary of War, now occupied with Commissioners of this State, of whom Mr Thayer is one, in surveying the ground between Weymouth and Taunton Rivers with view to the opening of a Canal, or the Construction of a Canal to unite them— Mrs Royall called only for a moment and finding company, withdrew. She is upon her return from Plymouth, and told me she should remain this Night at the village tavern. Judge Davis and his brother were here at tea. I spoke in condolence to the judge, upon the recent melancholy and sudden death of his Grandson Sturges, only Son of William Sturges; killed on board of a Vessel, by the gibing of a boom— A highly promising youth of 17. who was at the University; and who the judge said had never given cause of concern to his Relatives, but by his death— I paid an evening visit to Mr Marston; and on my return home, found Letters from R. Rush, Nathl. Frye jr. and B. O. Tyler— The last was from Harrisburg Pennsylvania, dated the 7th. instt and announced the very sudden decease there, on the Evening of the 6th. of Mr Robert Little, the Minister of the Unitarian Church at Washington— He died after an illness of little more than 24 hours, of an inflammation of the brain; after having preached morning and Evening at Harrisburg on Sunday the 5th. the day before his death— This is an event deeply to be lamented by his Congregation, of whom I was one. I had constantly attended on his ministration for the last seven years; though I had never formally joined his Society— I did not subscribe to many of his doctrines; particularly not to the fundamental one, of his unitarian creed— I believe in One God, but his nature is incomprehensible to me, and of the question between the Unitarians and the Trinitarians, I have no precise belief, because no definite Understanding. But Mr Little’s moral discourses were always good, and sometimes admirable— I listened to them with pleasure and profit; and shall miss them if I live to return to Washington— His place will not easily be supplied—

The Basket maker, from the town of Mansfield, Dean, called at the gate, and gave me an Oration in verse, delivered by his father at Stirling on the 4th. of July 1811. It is in six line Stanzas and printed at Boston— As he was going to Boston, with an empty waggon I asked him to take in an Easel, which Wheeler had borrowed of Mr Alston; and left here to be returned, which he did— The visitors who afterwards came before dinner were almost all strangers to me— One of the Loring’s told me he was Captain of the Company of New-England guards, when I visited them at their encampment at Savin Hill, Dorchester, in 1821. Mr Reynolds and the five who came with him were partly from Pennsylvania, and the rest from Boston— None of them known to me, but as they introduced themselves. I wrote all the morning, and after dinner rode in my Chaise with T. B. Adams junr. through Braintree to the Randolph Meeting Houses. We returned over a New, and well made Turnpike, and after being some time uncertain where we were, we came out at Milton, at the corner, whence the new Road proceeds to Dedham— The whole ride was of about twelve miles, and would have been very pleasant but that we were overtaken with rain; and the weather became cold— The young Whitneys and Greenleaf’s spent the Evening here— George Beale came to say that the fishing party was fixed for next Saturday, and to enquire at what time it would suit me to go. I named five in the Morning, which he thought too early— I then mentioned six, which he agreed to, though intimating, that it might yet be too soon for some of the company. Charles came out from Medford, and while I was gone, Dr George Parkman came to visit me. Since his last call he had sent me a medicinal potation, which he had recommended to me, and which I have used once with good effect.
15. V:5. Sun risen.

The morning was uninterrupted and I employed it in writing. Louisa Smith dined with us. After dinner I walked to Mr T. Greenleaf’s, and went with him to the Temple; to examine the cellar under it with a view to fix upon the spot where the vault is to be constructed for the tomb of my father and mother— Before going there, I visited the garden opposite to Mr Greenleaf’s house, where he has a number of rare plants, and trees not of the natural growth of this part of the Country— He is, as I propose to be, curious upon this subject, but he has already been many years in a course of experiments, and I have never been able to pursue with perseverance any. He has two flourishing Catalpa trees, and has so trained them, that they are erect and with branches well directed for growth and shade. He has the Laburnum, double flowered Althea’s, the Judas tree, and several others but has failed with the Magnolia. His English walnuts and others in this neighbourhood, were last Spring attacked by a bug which threatens them all, with destruction— I found on the back of one of the leaves, a cluster of about forty small yellow worms, each about one third of an inch long, which I intimated to Mr Greenleaf might be the larva, of that pernicious bug. He said if it was, by tracing its transformations, perhaps some hint might be collected, from which a remedy against his depredations might be devised— I therefore plucked the leaf, brought it home, and placed it under a glass Rummer. On examining the cellar of the Temple several places were pointed out to me, where I might at my option locate the Tomb, but before fixing upon it, I determined to take further time for consideration, and to consult friends. The estimates of the cost of the Temple, amount to 32000 dollars—but Mr. Greenleaf thinks the actual expense will fall short of 30000— This will require good fortune to be well carried through. The prospects as yet, are fair— The town and the parish have proceeded with great unanimity in the undertaking— Mr Greenleaf gave me copies of the votes of the Town, and of the Society, both of 6. November 1826. accepting the proposal I had made, by my Letter of 8. September 1826. to the Supervisors, and authorising them to make the contract with me as I had suggested— At the temple I met and recognized my Classmate Nathaniel Shepherd Prentiss; and also an old inhabitant of the town whom I remember from the days of my childhood, Wilson Marsh. After returning home I had visits from General H. A. S. Dearborn, and Commodore Bainbridge; and from Mr George Blake; Bainbridge is upon his return to Philadelphia having been with Commodores Chauncey and Morris to visit and inspect the Eastern Navy Yards— This Evening was so cold that I passed it in my chamber, writing Letters— Charles with T. B. Adams junr. and Elizabeth spent it at Daniel Greenleafs, and on his return informed me that Mr James Buchanans explanatory Letter was published in this day’s Centinel.

Messrs.Tucker and Dwelle are inhabitants of Boston, and inventors or proprietors of a new invented hydrometer, for measuring the strength of Spirituous liquors— Three or four years since they petitioned Congress representing that their hydrometer was much superior to that of Dycas, the use of which is prescribed by Law, at the Custom houses of the United States and praying that theirs might be substituted in its place. A Bill to that effect was introduced into the House of Representatives; but in its progress rival inventors appeared and laid in claims, so that the act of Congress was modified— It authorised the Treasury to cause examinations to be made, and to direct the substitution of the hydrometer which upon trial should be found the best— Experiments were accordingly made by direction of the Secretary of the Treasury at Boston, New-York and Philadelphia at the respective Custom-houses by the Collectors, assisted by scientific men. The report from the examination at Boston was altogether favourable to the hydrometer of Tucker and Dwelle: but at New-York there was a competitor named Southworth, and Professor M’Neven had received another hydrometer from France invented by Gay-Lussac, which he thought preferable to all the rest; while at Philadelphia, one of the examiners Professor Hare, had an invention of his own, and was about to publish a dissertation upon the subject himself. The Reports therefore from New-York and Philadelphia were rather unfavourable to the instrument of Tucker and Dwelle. Mr Rush then had experiments made at Washington under his own inspection— But the results upon the trial of all the hydrometers was so nearly the same, that he saw no justifiable cause for setting aside the hydrometer of Dycas— Tucker and Dwelle however still persisted— A second examination was directed at Boston about two Months since, the Report upon which was as favourable to them as the first had been— They came here this morning to enquire what had been done further in the matter; of which I was not informed, but advised them to write to the Secretary of the Treasury— I mentioned to them the untoward circumstances which had hitherto operated against them: that as there had been some prejudices and perhaps individual interests to influence the reports from New-York and Philadelphia, unfavourably, it was supposable on the other hand that a disposition to favour them might have influenced the Reports from Boston— They said there had been prejudice and no goodwill to them in the examinations at New-York and Philadelphia— That General Swift had in a very marked manner shewn his partiality for Southworth—as Dr Hare had done for his own intended publication. That the professors and scientific men with the exception of Dr M’Neven, appeared not to be so familiar with the use of the instruments, or so capable of judging of their relative value as the Distillers— That the superiority of their instruments to the others, was not in producing different results, but in the facility of using them, and in their durability. That twenty-two of the Distillers in Boston, that is all in the City but two had adopted their instrument for use in preference to that of Dycas, and one or more distillers in New York had done the same, though by a Law of the state it exposed them to a prosecution— I told them that I should very cheerfully sanction the substitution of their instrument when that measure could be justified by adequate evidence in its favour— But as it would necessarily cause expense it could not otherwise be done— Tucker said that although it would in the first instance occasion some expense it would be more than saved by the greater durability of their hydrometer— Mr Raguet is upon a Summer excursion with his family, and while here expressed a wish to see the house at the foot of Penn’s hill, where my father was born; to find which I gave him the necessary directions— The other visitors came in the morning except Mr Hammond who called at the dusk of evening, and told me he was going to New-Bedford his native place, but that his father had removed from it when he was a child, and he had never been there since— Charles went to Boston this morning; and he and George came out in the Stage this afternoon. The Sun rose clear, but clouds were gathering all the morning. Before noon it began to rain, which continued copiously till Bed time, and with the weather so cold that we had a fire in the dining parlour— I put under a glass two small white worms, of those, one of which feeds at the core, of almost every jargonelle Pear.
17. V. Morning Rain Storm.

The storm continued through the Night and this morning till near Noon, when the weather gradually cleared away chilling cool. Mr George Beale called to say that Mr and Mrs Quincy would go with us on the fishing party to-morrow, but thought that seven O’Clock would be early enough for embarking to which I readily assented— I had received yesterday a Letter from my wife of the 11th. at Long Branch, which I this day answered by a Letter directed to her there— Antoine drove Charles and me in a Carryall, with my horse to General H. A. S. Dearborn’s at Roxbury, where we dined— My brother and George were invited, but sent excuses— Commodores Bainbridge, Chauncey and Morris were there. Mrs. Bainbridge, a Miss Willard, and General Dearborn’s Lady and daughter. Messrs.Melville, GerryTracy, Wheeler, Marshal Harris and his two brothers, Fuller, Gorham, and D. L. Child— Conversation at dinner upon the Duke of Wellington and George Canning— Napoleon, General Jackson, and James Buchanan— Coll. T. H. Perkins who had been invited to the dinner, sent an excuse, some fine fruit and a toast— We left the table about seven, and I returned to Quincy— The weather was fair, but so cold and damp that having no outer garment, I reached home quite chilled, and the fire could scarcely warm me. I found at my brother’s Mr Charles Harrod, with his two daughters. He had just arrived from New-York, and New-Orleans— Says Mrs Silsbee of Salem, was a passenger with him from New-York, and told him she had seen my wife at the Theatre at New York last Monday Evening; and she was going the next day to Saratoga— I put under a glass this day three worms taken from Vine leaves— They are about half an inch long; have backs of buff colour, bordered by two black stripes length wise, and eleven black stripes crosswise; without hair— The family of walnut worms have as yet remained torpid on the leaf; but are changing to a dingy brown— There were several visitors who called in my absence this afternoon— Among whom were John Welles, Coll. H Sargent, Andrew Ritchie and a Mr Clark of South-Carolina.
18— V. Fishing party— Charles 20.

At seven this Morning the company for the fishing party assembled at the head of the Quincy Canal, and embarked in the Hingham Packet, Brilliant, Captain which was in readiness to receive them— They consisted of my brother and my Sons George and Charles, Mrs Baxter and her daughter, George Beale, Thomas Greenleaf, his wife and daughters Eliza and Mary Ann, Daniel Greenleaf and his wife, M’Alister of Georgia, John Marston, Edward Miller and his wife, Josiah Quincyhis wife, and daughters Sophie and Anna, and his Son Edmund, William Smith and his wife, Miss Wayles, a niece of Mr Beale’s, Peter Whitney the Minister, his wife, his Son George, and daughter Caroline, with myself in all twenty-nine. There was scarcely a breath of wind, and we were towed to the mouth of the canal, which is 3/4 of a mile-long. There we entered the town near by a lock, and passing by the Monatiquot and Weymouth rivers at the right hand and the Mount Wollaston farm, and Germantown at the left, we crossed over between Pethicks Island and Hull, and down through the Light House Channel, below Egg Rock, the Brewster’s and the Graves, about six Miles due East of these are the best fishing grounds, but we could not reach them— The weather was fair and moderate; but calm, with occasional very light easterly breezes— It was one O’Clock before we reached the Light-house and three before we came to a ground where cod were found— We lay to for fishing not more than half an hour, and caught about half a dozen cod, all very small but two of moderate size— One dozen of very small mackerel, and two or three other small fishes— Of the Cod, a Chowder was made; a plentiful ga gala for all the company. Mr Quincy, the Mayor, was the only successful fisherman of the day. I caught nothing— There was a very tight swell of the Sea, which made several of the Ladies and two or three of the men Sea sick. We had a pleasant Sail in returning and landed about six O’Clock at Bent’s point— I came home with George in Mr Edward Miller’s Carriage, with Mrs Miller and Mrs Smith who alighted at Mr. Edward Miller’s and Miss Wayles, who was taken to Mr G. Beale’s. We reached home just before Sunset— All much Sunburnt. I had also been suffering all day, with sharp rheumatic pain from the left shoulder blade down to the rains; the consequence of my last Evening’s ride without an outer Coat or Cloak— I found myself so unwell on returning home this Evening that I immediately retired to bed; leaving part of the despatches that I had received on board the Boat this morning to be read tomorrow— Put a large worm dropt from the barren vine at the Summer Garden, under a glass. The two small white worms that came from the Jargonelle Pears, have rolled themselves up in Cocoons, side by side, at the edge of the Rummer under which they were placed.
19. V:15. Sun risen.

After a feverish and painful night I found myself this morning somewhat relieved, but suffered with a remnant of rheumatism, through the day. Heard Mr Fiske of Menotomy, in the morning from Hebrews 10.39. “But we are not of them who draw back unto perdition; but of them that believe to the saving of the Soul.” and in the afternoon from Romans 15.13 “Now the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, that ye may abound in hope, through the power of the Holy Ghost.” The two Sermons appeared to be parts of one discourse, and although Mr Fiske is one of those who pass under the denomination of liberal preachers; yet his comments upon the terms perdition, and saving of the Soul, gave no countenance to the doctrine of universalism— Without recurring to the usual common place arguments of the Calvinistic School, upon Faith, he dwelt impressively upon the joy, and peace and hope of believing—without however specifying any particular article of belief— Mr Fiske was a very old acquaintance of mine, and two years before me at the University I had not seen him for many years; and sent him an invitation to dine with us, but he was engaged. My brother took his Son Isaac Hull to Roxbury to rejoin his School. George was confined all day to the house, very unwell. Day and evening without visitors.

Mr Cary is from Bridgwater and came to renew a solicitation for the appointment of his Son in Law Dunham as keeper of a Light house now building in the State of Maine— I was not sure whether the place was yet open or had been filled a few days before I left Washington. Cary asked me if I remembered a Company of Militia, who about the time of the Battle of Lexington in 1775. came down from Bridgwater, and passed the Night at my father’s house and barn at the foot of Penn’s Hill; and in the midst of whom, my father placed me, then a boy between seven and eight years, and I went through the manual exercise of the musket, by word of command from one of them— I told him I remembered it as distinctly as if it had been last week— He said he was one of that company. Coll. Thayer Superintendent of the Academy at West-Point called here to take leave, being on his return to his Post— He has been upon a short visit to his father, who resides at Braintree, where he was born. He said he had Letters to a late date from the Point, and they were entirely satisfactory as to the present condition of the School, and conduct of the Cadets. He also mentioned that there would shortly be two or three professors to be appointed. Mr Gray is the Minister at Jamaica Plains. R. G. Amory who came with his Son in Law Captain Freeman, invited me to dine with him on Thursday. Of our afternoon visitors Mrs Whittemore and Mr Loring are Relations of ours from Hingham. Mr Loring urged me to make one of a party with other friends from Hingham to visit Nantasket Beach, which I promised I would. De Grand came out from Boston, with Mr Brown, who was a delegate from Boston to the recent manufacturing interest Convention at Harrisburg, Pennsylvania; which he says was conducted and terminated very harmoniously. Lieutenant Schuler is the officer who last May was tried by a Court Martial, upon two sets of Charges— Sentenced to be dismissed upon both; but the remission of the Sentence was in both cases recommended by the Court. It was accordingly remitted, and I added an expression of regret that the charges had been made subjects of a Court-Martial— He now came with great familiarity to tell me that he had been much hurt by the Sentences of the Court-Martial, that he wanted to get away from the army—would be glad to be attached to the academy at West-Point or to the Artillery School of practice at Point comfort, or anything to get away from the army And he asked my advice what he should do; observing, that he might be insulted, I advised him to repair to his Post, and by the strict and undeviating propriety of his conduct to remove any unfavourable impression left by the decisions of the Court-Martial. That by such conduct, he would recover his character, and probably avoid insult—but if he should be insulted, he would have the remedies provided by the laws in such cases— He thanked me for this advice, said he would follow it, and went away But his deportment drew the notice of the company present, and his breath was inflammible. He said he would go to see Coll. Thayer at Braintree, but I informed him that the Coll. had left that place.
I spent the Evening with my brother and his family at Mr Marston’s— My Son Charles went this morning to Boston, to reside, and to pursue his study of the Law in the Office of Mr Webster— My brother and his Son Thomas went to Boston this Morning, and returned to dinner— Thomas brought me out a heavy Mail of despatches and Letters, which the whole afternoon, allowed me not time sufficient to read through— George went after dinner to Boston with Antoine, who returned here in the Evening— I wrote to the Secretary of the Treasury, and enclosed the Petitions and papers of Henry Fry and Charles Anderson, with orders for the discharge of Fry from prison, and for the remission of the penalties incurred by Anderson, Master of the British ship Newry for bringing from that place to New York, an excess of 18 passengers. I wrote also to N. Frye junr and T. J. Hellen.
21. V. Bath— Dined at Boston with D Webster— Returned at Night to Quincy

The coldness of the weather, rains, and a smart touch of Rhumatism, at the close of last week, have interrupted my Seawater baths till this morning when at 10. I went in at the wharf with T. B. Adams junr. and with Antoine— At eleven the Mayor of Boston came out with Governor Kent of Maryland his two Aide de Camps Colls Culbreth and Doane, a Mr and Mrs Peyton of Richmond, Virginia, with their Son and Miss Ritchie, daughter to the Editor of the Richmond Enquirer. They had been visiting the railway, which was one of the Governor’s objects in this excursion from his State— He told me that he had seen my wife, and her part of the family, at Saratoga Springs last Thursday Evening. He said he proposed leaving Boston, upon his return home next Friday— At a quarter past two I went with Antoine into Boston, and called at Dr. Welsh’s where I saw his daughter Harriet, and my Son George, who came out to Quincy in the Stage. I dined at Mr Webster’s with Governor Kent and his aids, Mr Bailey from the Eastern Shore of Maryland, Messrs.Thorndike, B. Joy, G Blake, D. Sears, W. Elliot, T. Fuller, and two or three others. Mrs Webster told me that Mr and Mrs Agg, had been these five or six weeks at Boston. Mr Thornton urged me warmly to pay him a visit at Beverley. In the Evening I returned to Quincy, and found company at my brothers. Mr and Mrs John Greenleaf, with Louisa Smith, and Mary Norton, Mr Marston and his family, Mr G. Beale and his niece Miss Wayles— A Son of Mr Pleasonton was also here, a visitor to T. B. Adams junr. Louisa Smith told me she should return to Boston to-morrow. I wrote to the Secretary of War— Planted Plumstones, and apple and pear seeds in seedling bucket N. 3.— One of the striped Vine worms chrysalized this day on a Vine leaf— The English walnut worms feed, grow, and have turned nearly black.
22. IV:30: Sun rose at 5: Dined at Roxbury with T. K. Jones.

Pleasonton went off this morning. He is of the party, engaged in the Surveys between Weymouth and Taunton rivers— Mrs Adams with her son Thomas went to Hingham. I had morning visits from Mr Gay, formerly a Classmate of my brother Charles, and Dr Fiske, a Son of my Classmate— Dined, with my brother, and my Son George at Mr T. K. Jones’s at Roxbury. In company with my old friends and acquaintance, Dr Porter of Roxbury and Dr. Harris of Dorchester— James Lloyd, Rufus G. Amory, John Parker, Peter C. Brooks, (and one of his Sons) Benjamin Buzzy, R. G. Shaw— C. Loring, Captain Freeman, and seven or eight Strangers to me; one a Mr Ford from New-York— We returned early in the Evening to Quincy— I wrote short Letters this day to R. Rush: and to N. Edwards, the Governor of the State of Illinois— I planted this day in my Seedling bucket N. 4. Six Catherine Pear Seeds— Two of the small striped worms chrysalized, one on a leaf, and the other on the bottom of the tumbler. I put under a Rummer a worm of the Caterpillar form, about an inch long—white hairy with eight black spots along the middle of the back, and two rows of small black specks at the sides— Taken from a high blackberry leaf. One more shagbark walnut has come up in my Summer house nursery. It first appeared last Thursday a simple stem so small that I doubted if it was a tree— This morning the putting forth of leaves from the top of the stem was first apparent.

Mrs. Adamsmy brothers wife was taken ill last Evening, and was all this day confined to her bed— Dr Holbrook was sent for this morning, and I took the opportunity of consulting him on the state of my own health— Since my arrival here it is better than it had been for several months, but the sluggish operations of the Stomach and costive habit continues— He approved of the potion sent me last week by Dr Parkman, but said he would bring me some pills— As I was going down to the wharf with George, the boys and Antoine, I met Dr Channing, and Mr Richard Dana in a Chaise, coming from Cambridge to pay me a visit— I turned back and received them. Richard Dana, is the youngest Son of my early friend judge Francis Dana— He lives with his two Sisters at Cambridge and invited me to visit them there— After they were gone, I took a short bath and swim at the wharf, and found on my return Mr Gray; who on behalf of the Corporation of Harvard University, invited me to attend next Wednesday at the annual Commencement, and the following day at the declamations for the Boylston prizes, and they repeated the invitation to a formal reception in the Philosophy chamber— This I explicitly declined, on account of the illness of President Kirkland, who will not only be unable to go through the performances of the day, but by advice of his physician will be absent from Cambridge— I desired Mr Gray to return my thanks to the Corporation for their kind invitations, and say that I had engagements on Wednesday and Thursday, which rendered it doubtful whether I could attend at the performances of either day— That I requested them therefore to make all their arrangements as if I should not be there, and to receive me as an ordinary stranger if I should. With my brother, and my Son George I dined at Mr Rufus G. Amory’s at Roxbury— His daughter and her husband, Captain Freeman reside with him. General and Mrs Scott, and her mother Mrs Mayo, Commodore and Mrs Bainbridge, a Mrs Taylor, from Nova-Scotia, my old Classmate Jonathan Amory and his Son, Mr Buzzy, Mr Jeffers who married, another daughter of Rufus, John GrayJohn Callender, a Mr Read of Philadelphia and two or three others constituted the company— We came home later than last Evening. I reached home at the ringing of the Evening Bell. Mr George Beale invited me to the annual dinner of the Directors of Neponset Bridge, next Tuesday week— I wrote to H. Clay, and planted 4. Office-tree apple-seeds in seedling Bucket N. 2.
24. V:— Bath— Boston— Hamilton’s Exchange Hotel— Dined at T. L. Winthrop’s.

On my return from Mr Amory’s last Evening, I received a Note from Harriet Welsh, enclosing two Letters from John Lane Boylston at Princeton to Mr Curtis of Roxbury, the first dated the 19th. acknowledging the receipt of a Letter from Curtis to his father on business; but stating that he was too ill, to be able to answer it; and advising him to dissuade visitors from coming to Princeton, as his father could not see even all his own family— The second was of the 21st. dictated by Mr Boylston himself, but written and signed by his Son, and representing him as nearly at the last extremity— There was an endorsement on this second Letter of 9. O Clock in the Evening: saying there was no alteration— Mr Gray the Minister of Jamaica Plains called on me this morning, and said Mr Curtis would himself go off this afternoon to Princeton, and said he should write by him— He enquired if I had any message to send— I desired him to say that I felt deep concern, at being informed of Mr Boylston’s illness, and anxiously hoped to hear soon of his recovery— That in that event I proposed to visit him before I should return to Washington, and in the mean time, if there was any thing that I could do for him, or Mrs Boylston, I was at their service— Mr Gray mentioned that his Son was going to France, and enquired how he could obtain a Passport, and asked a Letter of introduction for him to Mr Brown our Minister at Paris— I told him that a Passport would be furnished, upon application by Letter to the Secretary of State, but declined giving a Letter to Mr Brown, on the principle of invariable established usage— Dr Holbrook called, and left with me a box of his pills— I bathed
at the wharf with my brothers Sons Isaac Hull, who had come from School, John Quincy and Joseph Harrod; and immediately afterwards I came with Antoine in to Boston, and took lodging at the Exchange Hotel— I called at Dr Welsh’s— He told me that Mr Curtis was already gone for Princeton. I dined with my Sons George and Charles at the Lieutenant Governor’s T. L. Winthrop— General Scott, Commodores Bainbridge and Chauncey, Coll. House, Captain Gallagher, Edward Everett, Mr Pierpont and some others were of the company. In the evening I visited successively judge Joseph Hall, and Mr Cruft, with whom I agreed to go early tomorrow morning and see the Marine Railway. Between nine and ten I returned to my lodgings at the Exchange Hotel
25. IV:45. Medford with Charles— Peter Chardon Brooks’s.

At half past five this morning, Mr Cruft called with his two Sons Samuel Breck, and William Smith, and I walked with them down to the Marine Railway; a recent invention for hauling up ships on a cradle, to repair them instead of the old practice of heaving them down. There are two of the ways, which are of Cast-Iron and Oak-timber from New-York—brought down the Canal from Lake Erie— The reason assigned for which was that no Oak timber of sufficient size could be obtained here— There was a Schooner upon one of the ways and a brig upon the other— They told me that This Railway was first put in operation last December since which they had already taken up and repaired 57 vessels besides the two now on the ways— But the establishment, with the land they have purchased and the buildings they have erected has cost them near a hundred thousand dollars; and the profits of their business, make no adequate return for this expenditure. We walked round, by the old Winisimet Ferry, Charles river Bridge, the site of the filled up old Mill-Pond, and back by the magnificent new Market House the Long-wharf and State-Street, back to my lodgings— The improvements in the City are very great and very costly— They are the proofs of prosperity, which may a good Providence continue, and of a Spirit of enterprize, that deserves its reward— After breakfast I remained till 2. P.M. at the Exchange, and received the visitors named in the margin, and two or three others, not known or not remembered. I then rode out with Charles to Mr Brooks’s at Medford; having engaged to pass the Sunday with him— He resides at a very convenient, and sufficiently elegant Country Seat, several Miles from Boston. There were here at dinner, Mr Benjamin Gorham, brother of Mrs Brooks and member elect from Boston, in the House of Representatives of the United States— Mr Edward Everett, who married the second daughter of Mr Brooks, and member of the House from the Middlesex district; Edward, and P. C. Brooks junr. two of his Sons; and Mr Stetson the Minister of the Congregational Church in Medford at which Mr Brooks attends. Mrs Brooks is the daughter of Nathanael Gorham of Charlestown whom I first knew at London in the year 1783. and who was afterwards a member and President of the Confederation Congress and of the Convention of 1787. which made the Constitution of the U.S. I had not been acquainted with Mrs Brooks before— I have known Mr Brooks many years. Their daughter Abigail Brown was with her Sister Mrs Everett, last Winter at Washington, where my Son contracted an engagement with her. But as they are both underage, and Charles has yet a year of Law studies to accomplish before he can be admitted to the Bar, their marriage was postponed until that time. Mr Brooks has living seven sons and three daughters; none of whom except Abby, now reside with them— The eldest daughter is married to Mr Frothingham, Minister of the first Congregational Church at Boston. Their Son Thomas a boy of seven or eight years is here.

I walked early this morning with Mr Brooks round his grounds, which are well cultivated, and ornamented with more regard to usefulness than show— The Middlesex Canal passes through his garden, and serves as a fence to it— There is beyond it also a large pond of which he has also the benefit as if it were part of his own Estate— He has a Shower bath, conducted by a pipe from the waters of the Canal; and numerous fruit and forest trees of his own raising— The day was lowering so that we walked but partially over the grounds. We attended at Meeting, and heard a young man named G. W. Burnap, a nephew of the late Governor Brooks—in the morning from Psalm 122.1. [“]I was glad when they said unto me Let us go into the House of the Lord”— The Sermon was well composed and divided considering successively the propriety, the advantages, and the pleasures of public religious worship. The afternoon Sermon was from Galatians 6.7. “Be not deceived: God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap. 8. For he that soweth to his flesh, shall of the flesh reap corruption: but he that soweth to the Spirit shall of the Spirit reap life everlasting.” The discourses were both short— Soon after our return from the afternoon service, Mr Everett came with Mr Joseph M’Ilvaine of Philadelphia, and Mr Peter C. Brooks junr. with his wife who is a daughter of Mr John Heard— They took tea with the family and then returned to Boston— Mr Brooks junr. brought the news of the arrival of Mr Frothingham last Evening from New-York, and from Europe— Also that Mr Henry Wainwright, a person with whom I was formerly well acquainted was last evening drowned as he went to bathe at one of the Bridge bathing houses— There were in the Evening from thirty to forty men of the respectable inhabitants of Medford, who came and were introduced to me— Also Mr Brooks’s two Sisters Mrs Hall, with her husband and daughter, and Mrs Gray, widow of Samuel Gray, and two daughters. Mrs Hall remembered that she had been my partner at a dance at her mother’s house about January 1787. while I was at the University, when I was suddenly seized with a violent cramp in the legs which disabled me for the Night— I well remember the incident though I had forgotten my partner— There came on this Evening a North-east Storm with heavy Rain.
27. V. Boston— Quincy.

After Breakfast this morning, I came with Mr Brooks in his Carriage into Boston, with his daughter Abigail, my Son Charles, and Thomas Frothingham, Mr Brooks’s Grandson. I alighted at Mr James H. Fosters; a servant brought in my Chaise and left it at Mr Gragg’s stable— There was a heavy rain— I desired Charles to find if he could his brother George; and to procure my packets of Letters from the Post Office— At Mr Foster’s I saw his wife, and two daughters, Elizabeth and Louisa, and Louisa Smith— After waiting near two hours at Mr Foster’s, no appearance of Charles, and the rain pouring more and more, almost in floods; I determined at all Events to come out before dinner to Quincy. Mrs Foster sent to Mr Gragg’s stable a boy who brought me the Chaise, but I was obliged to return to the Stable for my trunk and Night-bag. I then came out to Quincy alone, with heavy rain the whole way— Mrs Foster had urged me to stay and dine with them; but having intended to come out to dine, I could not brook the feeling of being locked up in Boston. I found my brother’s family at dinner, with Mr Charles Harrod, his daughter, and a small boy. My Son George was also here, my brother had gone to Boston in the Stage, and returned this Evening— There was a large budget of Letters, despatches and Newspapers— I wrote to the Secretary of the Treasury, and enclosed to him two Petitions: one from William Macdonald, late Assistant Inspector Genl. U.S. army, in Chilicothe jail for debt to U.S. with an order endorsed for his release; and one from William Burton Master of the British Brig Union, of White Haven, from Cork to New-York with an order endorsed for the remission of the forfeitures of Vessel and Cargo, for having touched at Shelburne, Nova-Scotia, for provisions— This gave me full occupation for the afternoon till dark— In the evening we had music on the Piano with singing by Mr Harrod’s daughter, and my brother’s Son Isaac Hull— The weather was so cold that we had a fire in the dining room— As I was retiring to bed, I found the Sky had cleared off, to bright Star-light.

The day was fine and autumnal— Mr Harrod, with his daughter, and the small boy F. Foster, son of Phineas Foster went away this morning. Thomas B.
