Adams junr left us immediately after dinner, to return to West Point. His mother went with him to Boston, and returned in the Evening. Messrs.Britton and Goble were Strangers from Elizabeth-town, and Newark, New-Jersey, travelling in this part of the Country; and who visited this town to see the Railway and the President— I rode this afternoon with Mr Thomas Greenleaf to the Quarry near the Railway, where the four Columns, for the Temple have just been severed from the Rock— They are not yet hammered; but are to be four feet three inches in diameter, and twenty-three feet long, and are to be delivered, exact upon the spots where they are to stand, at one thousand dollars each. Mr Marden the proprietor of this ledge, and whom we found with eight or ten Stone Cutters at work upon it, thinks the Quarry at the Railway ledge not a good one— On returning from this we walked to the ledge belonging to Mr Greenleaf, where we found about an equal number of men at work; and they had there two columns in preparation for the Washington Bank at Boston. I called in a few minutes at Mr Greenleaf’s and with him, and his Son Price, viewed the trees in his fruit garden— I walked home, and found Mr Brooks, the Minister of Hingham, and Mr Loring here. They invited us for Thursday to Hingham for a ride to Nantasket Beach, and a fishing party. Mr Brooks invited us to tea at his house after our return— Mr Benjamin Buzzy came with his daughter Mrs Davis, a widow, and invited us to dine with him on Friday the 7th. of September, and before dinner to visit his woollen manufactory at Dedham; which invitation I accepted. I had engaged to dine with Dr. George Parkman, at Boston, on Thursday the 6th. I received this morning a large mail of despatches and Letters, among which one from my wife, and one from my Son John, at Saratoga, going to Lebanon. I answered my wife’s Letter, and wrote a short one to H. Clay— Spent the Evening alone with George, in his Chamber— There was a remarkable and uncommonly bright Aurora Borealis; and a far more uncommon luminous vapour girdle which extended from the Southeastern to the North western horizon; about the apparent width of the milky way, but far more luminous, and evidently a mere atmospheric phenomenon— Its motion was as rapid as that of clouds in light winds, and it was gradually disappearing when I retired to bed. I have three new Shagbark walnut trees, come up in my Summer house nursery.
29. V: Commencement Day— Bath — Visit to C. Tufts at Weymouth.

There is a young Lady here a visitor, by the name of Sparhawk: of New-Hampshire, whose father was some years Secretary of that State— It being Commencement day at Cambridge, I was without interruption of visitors— I passed the morning at writing. Bathed at the wharf, between three and four in the afternoon, and rode with my brothers son Isaac Hull, by the old Road over Penn’s Hill to Weymouth; and paid a visit to Mr Tufts— Returned over the Turnpike Bridge, and found my son Charles had come out from Boston— He has been much indisposed in consequence of taking cold in the rain storm of Monday. I wrote to the Secretary of the Navy, and answered the Letter of Mrs Stebbins the daughter of Mr Stuart the painter— Dr Holbrook called here this afternoon; and I informed him that I had not taken any of his pills, having had no occasion for them— The improvement of my health is gradual, and its restoration might be perfect, if I could remain longer here. But it would probably require more time than I have to bestow, and I look forward already without pleasure to the necessity of my return to Washington— Dr Holbrook is himself much out of health— Mr George Beale was here this evening, and we agreed to fix upon next Saturday morning, for our second fishing excursion, and to take our departure from Bent’s Point, at seven O’Clock in the Morning— The day that had been thought of was Friday, but our party from Hingham is to be to-morrow; and I was desirous of having a day of interval between the two parties; for writing and attention to business.— I discovered another Shagbark walnut tree come up, in my Summer-house Nursery, and there are two, said to be Elms and self-planted.

At half past six this morning, my brother with his Son Isaac Hull, and myself with Antoine, in two Chaises went to Hingham, and stopped at the House of Mr Thomas Loring, where we saw him, and Mrs Whittemore; and his Son— Mrs Loring was confined to her chamber by Indisposition. We then immediately proceeded upon our party to Cohasset. I went with Mr Loring the son in his Chaise and his servant-man, rode with Antoine in mine— Mr Thomas Thaxter, and his Son in Law Edward Thaxter, Norton Quincy, Son of Quincy Thaxter, Martin Lincoln, a Son of the old Revolutionary General Benjamin Lincoln, deceased, and Dr Fiske, and Mr Ebenezer Gay, constituted our company. We went to the Houses of the two Nicholls’s on the Cohasset Sea-Shore, and thence in a boat to the outer of the two Rocks called the Black Rock, from which we fished about three hours, and caught about eight dozen Sea perch, and a very few other small fishes— We then returned in a very leaky boat to the shore, and dined at the further Nicholls’s Mr Brooks the Minister of Hingham then joining the party— An unfortunate accident, marred its pleasures, my horse having kicked the servant man named William Nelson, who was with Mr Loring— He was struck on one arm, and on the lower stomach, but by the saving mercy of Providence, not severely wounded— He fell at the first shock; but soon recovered, and was not disabled from attending the horses, and returning with us to Hingham. On that return we rode over about two miles of the Nantasket Beach, the tide being nearly high— It was the first time I had ever visited this magnificent Scene: but a low tide, and a stormy day, are the times for seeing it, in its highest sublimity— On reaching Hingham I visited Mr Quincy Thaxter, whom I saw with his two daughters, and their aged Aunt Celia— Then at Mr Thomas Thaxter’s where I saw his wife, and daughter, the wife of Edward Thaxter: after which I joined again the fishing party who took tea at Mr Brooks’s— Then at the dusk of Evening we came home to Quincy; I with my brother in his Chaise, and his Son Isaac with Antoine in mine— In riding this afternoon with Mr Loring we met at a narrow passage of the road a Chaise, in which were three Ladies and so unskilfully driven that the wheels of the two Chaises became interlocked before the horses could be stopped, and two seconds more would have produced a shock and a crash which must have endangered the lives and limbs of all who were in either Chaise— Two most deplorable accidents were thus most narrowly escaped in this day, and I had two solemn warnings of the numberless incidents by which a party of pleasure is often converted into an irreparable calamity. Praise the Lord O my Soul, and be not unmindful of his benefits— George went to Boston this morning and returned at Night.
31. V. Bath.

At six this morning I bathed at the wharf with my nephews Isaac Hull, and John Quincy, and Antoine— The water was so cold that I remained in it, not more than five minutes. Mr Price Greenleaf came over and budded several Plum trees in the garden, and front yard, with Apricot buds which he brought with him, and large plums the slips of which had been given to my brother. Mr M’Alister called in the forenoon, and gave an account of the Commencement at Cambridge and the Boylston prize declamations and Φ.B.K. Oration by Mr Walker of Charlestown, and Poem by Dr Gamaliel Bradford jr. of Boston. I had two old Pear trees, nearly dead, cut down in the Garden, with the intention of supplying their places; but Mr Greenleaf says that young trees will not thrive in the same places where old ones of the same kind have stood— I wrote to Mr Clay, and occupied the morning with writing; and twice made the attempt to ride over to Dorchester to visit Mr John Bailey— We had just turned the corner of my late uncle Adams’s house, when we met Mr Mills the late Senator of the United States with Harriet Welsh coming to visit me— I turned back and received them— Mr Mills, appears to be more recovered from his illness than could have been expected last Spring when he left Washington, but he is still
much emaciated, and very feeble— At the second trial to go with George to Dorchester we had scarcely passed by Mr George Beales House, when we met Governor Levi Lincoln, Mr James D’Wolf heretofore a Senator from Rhode-Island, and General William H. Sumner, in a Coach— I turned back again, and gave up the visit to Mr Bailey for this day— Governor Lincoln has been some days at Boston, to attend the annual Commencement at Cambridge— He spoke of the late correspondence between his brother Enoch Lincoln the Governor of Maine, and the Secretary of State, relating to our controversy with Great-Britain, concerning the North-Eastern boundary, and expressed much regret at the temper which the Governor of Maine had exhibited in it— Apologised for his brother with proper brotherly regard, and said he had informed him that there was no participation here in that excitement which he had shewn; or in the pretension which he seemed to have advanced, that all the documents of a Negotiation with a foreign Government should be communicated to him, as Executive of a State interested in the issue, even while the Negotiation was pending— I said I had perceived with much regret the earnest apprehensions which the Governor of Maine had expressed in the Correspondence alluded to, as to the progress and result of the Negotiation— That with regard to the documents, the greatest objection to furnishing him with copies of them all was the great mass of them comprizing many folio Volumes— That there had never been the slightest disposition to conceal any one of them from the Government of Maine, and that they had been at all times open to the inspection of every member of the delegation in Congress from the State— That the solicitude felt by the Governor of Maine for the issue of the Negotiation, was duly appretiated by me as arising from an anxious sense of his own duty and the deep interest of the State in the Event— That assuredly no sacrifice of that interest would ever be sanctioned by me; but that from the present temper of the British Government, shewn not only in this but upon every other point in discussion with us, the prospects of an early and satisfactory result were absolutely desperate. It was extremely doubtful whether even the Commercial Convention of 1818 would be renewed. As to this North-eastern boundary there was an express engagement which bound the parties to refer the question to the decision of a friendly Sovereign; but the Commissioners had disagreed upon the facts, as upon every thing else; and there was and could be no issue made up, until a statement of facts could be agreed upon between the two Governments to be submitted to the arbitrator— Mr Gallatin was now engaged in effecting this with the British Plenipotentiaries, but whether it could be accomplished was altogether uncertain— The Spirit of the present British Administration was so inveterately hostile, that unless some change should take place there I could not promise myself any favourable termination to the negotiations with them— The Governor said that the reference itself of the question of boundary to any foreign Sovereign, was a subject of great aversion to the State of Maine; but that he himself had entire confidence in the Constitutional organ of negotiation. That he proposed in a short time to visit Portland in Maine, where he expected to see his brother, and should converse freely with him upon these concerns, and hoped to remove some of the apprehensions which he had harboured— He invited me to visit him again at Worcester, in the most friendly manner, observing that he might not have another opportunity of seeing me here, before my return to Washington. I assured him of the great satisfaction which I had enjoyed in my visit to him last year, and of the pleasure, which I should take in repeating it; but observed that the illness of Mr Boylston rendered it doubtful whether I could go this year by the way of Princeton, and in that case it might not be in my power to go by the way of Worcester. He then said he would endeavour to see me again here before my return— He spoke with regret of the unfavourable issue of the Elections for Congress in Kentucky, the information of which has been first received this day— I had notice of it by a Letter from Mr Clay. After the Governor went away I walked with Elizabeth to Mr Marston’s, where with my brother’s family I passed the Evening— We were in going overtaken by the skirts of a thunder shower and took a slight sprinkling. There was at Mr Marston’s a Coll. Goodwin of Pawtucket; and the young Ladies of the School.

Day. I rise on the average about five— Journalize till half past seven. Breakfast, visit my Seedling Nursery and the Garden— Read Letters, despatches and Newspapers, write Letters, or Journal and receive visitors till two— Dine, and devote the afternoon to riding, visitors, and idleness— Evening the same till its close about ten. This life is diversified by bathing at the high tides, excursions, dinners, and fishing parties.
